description:
This is purely based on code inspection, but the compute API method 'evacuate' does not check if the specified host (if there was one) is different from instance.host. It checks if the service is up on that host, which could be down and you can still specify the instance.host.

Eventually the compute API will RPC cast to conductor task manager which will fail with an RPC error trying to RPC cast to the ComputeManager.rebuild_instance method on the compute service, which is down.

The bug here is that instead of getting an obvious 400 error from the API, you're left with not much for details when it fails. There should be an instance action and finish event, but only the admin can see the traceback in the event. Also, the instance.task_state would be left in 'rebuilding' state, and would require it to be reset to use the instance again.
title: os-migrateLive API does not restrict one from trying to migrate to the original host

comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~mriedem

comments.content: I've marked this as low severity since it's been a latent bug for a long time and is really just a safeguard against someone shouldn't actually do unless they screwed up.
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~mriedem

comments.content:
Note that the failure mode is different based on if the force flag is True or not.

1. force=True, host=instance.host: conductor will bypass the scheduler and eventually fail the RPC cast to the compute, resulting in the instance left in 'rebuilding' state.

2. force=False, host=instance.host: conductor will call the scheduler which should fail with NoValidHost; this will at least reset the instance.task_state to None.
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~mriedem

comments.content: The same issue exists for the live migration API if you specify a host and it's the same as instance.host.
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~mriedem
